div.head: RUSSIANS IN EGYPTIAN WATERS.
div.p: We publish to-day some interesting news from our Suez Correspondent on the subject of the warnings which are being addressed to the captains of British ships passing through the Canal as to the extraordinarily cautious behaviour which must be observed by them when the Russian fleet is by. That the Russians are still in a state of great nervous tension is obvious from the extract we published yesterday from the Rus. That St. Petersburg newspaper declared last week that the possibility of a Japanese attack in Egyptian waters is proved by reports which have been received from Admiral Rodjestvensky throughout the route. We must expect, therefore, that the Russians will be quite as liable to fall victims to grotesque panic in their journey through the Canal as they were in the North Sea. The continued presence on the seas of a squadron, commanded by officers so irresponsible and so inhuman as those who were guilty of the recent outrage, is as great a danger to 5 humanity at large as a mad and dangerousbull wandering over a field through which there is a public right of way. This is clearly recognised by the Egyptian authorities, and so, at the request of the Governor of Suez, all British ships are to be warned against throwing anything overboard while the fleet is passing.. Even "all mooring boats are to be hoisted on board at the time." These injunctions are eloquent of Egypt's recognition of the incompetence and ignorance of Russian seamanship. If an orange peel is cast overboard when the fleet is passing it will doubtless be mistaken for a hand grenade, while a mooring boat may be easily held to have a pivot gun. in the bow by persons who cannot tell the difference between trawlers and torpedo-boats. So long as the Baltic Fleet is travelling to the Far East there is always a danger that its presence in neutral waters may result in international complications. This is a point which has evidently not been lost sight of in the highest quarters. The publication of the latest despatches from General Stoessel, as this morning's telegrams remark, stops on the 3rd inst., and this fact is very significant, for those who are responsible for withholding them are also responsible for the issue of the fleet from the Baltic, and they are perfectly aware of the improbability of the arrival of the fleet in the China seas in time to save the great fortress. As long, therefore, as the Russian Grand Ducal firebrands are supreme at the Admiralty, the action of the wandering war fleet must be regarded as inspired by this reckless gang of political gamblers, who, despondent of success against Japan, recognise the impossibility of an escape from the Far Eastern impasse without a fresh diversion to rally popular sentiment to their bankrupt interests.

div.head:
PORT ARTHUR.
GEN, STOESSEL'S DESPATCHES,
THE GENERAL'S TRIUMPH.
div.p: The despatches from General Stoessel brought by the Raztorpny, which are dated 25th and 30th October and 3rd November, have been published. They show that the Russians lost 500 men in repelling the assaults on the 25th and 26th October. The last report, dated on Accession Day, is couched in a tone of the most fervent loyalty. The General rejoices in his triumph because the assaults, uninterrupted during nine days, were finally repulsed on this great day, when the Japanese had sworn to take the fortress. The telegrams from General Stoessel which have been published do not contain a hint of any impending disaster, but the fact that nothing has been published since the 3rd November is significant. (Reuter.)

div.head:
ON THE SHA-HO.
RUSSIANS ANTICIPATE BATTLE.
div.p: Reuter's correspondent, cabling yesterday, - says that the Japanese are moving a consider rable number of troops behind a screen of forti- ofications on the Sha-Ho. The Russians anti- cipate a battle.

div.head:
THE BALTIC FLEET.
MORE VESSELS LEAVE LIBAU.
RUMOURED HITCH IN NEGOTIATIONS.

div.p: Russia proposes only a few verbal alterations to the British draft regarding the convention, which it is expected in official circles will be speedily signed.
Five cruisers and eight torpedo-boats have left to complete the squadron.

A supplementary Baltic Fleet, consisting of five cruisers, including the former Volunteer vessels Petersburg and Smolensk, renamed Rion and Dnieper respectively, and eight torpedo-boats, left here yesterday, and passed Bornholm to-day.
The Russian Fleet has left for Accra. (R.)
Markets flat on rumours of a serious hitch in the wording of the convention as regards the punishing of the officers.

The rumour of a hitch has been exaggerated. Nothing has occurred beyond what was indicated in this morning's messages. The Russians are desiring to modify the clause relative to the culpability of the officers, and wish to ensure that the enquiry shall be confined to the facts. (Reuter.)
It appears that the blowing up of the Raztorpay was due to the fear of a repetition of the Reckitelni seizure.

After the commander had informed the Tao-tai of his decision to disarm, he gave the word, for the ship to be evacuated, and for the fuses to be lighted. As the boats approached the shore, three dull explosions were heard, and the destroyer immediately settled down and sank. (Reuter.)
Three Japanese destroyers entered the har bour this morning, and left after satisfying themselves that the Rastorpny had sunk. (R.)

div.head: THE "GROMJBJI" REPAIRED.
div.p: A blockade runner which has returned from Vladivostok confirms the news that the Gromoboi has been repaired.

At the banquet given last night at Windsor Castle, His Majesty, in proposing the health of the King of Portugal, announced that an Arbitration Treaty between the two countries was signed yesterday at Windsor. (Reuter.)
The King and Queen of Portugal are lunching at the Guildhall to-day. (Reuter.)

div.head: DELATION IN FRANCE
div.p: The Chamber of Deputies has adjourned an interpellation regarding civil officials accused of delation.

div.head: THE BRITISH STEAM YACHT
div.p: Emerald, which left our harbour last Sunday, returned this morning.

div.head: GREEK FLEET SUBSCRIPTION.-
div.p: The subscriptions in Cairo for the Greek Fleet reached a total of L.E. 5,500 on the opening day.

div.head: ABBAS HELMY THEATRE.-
div.p: The account of last night's performance of Carmen is held over until to-morrow.

div.head: THE IMPORTERS OF COTTON GOODS
div.p: will meet at the Alexandria Custom-house on the 23rd inst. at 10a.m. to elaborate a new tarif

div.head: THE COAST GUARD
div.p: S.S. Abdul Moneim has gone into the Khedivial Mail Company's dry- dock at Suez to be overhauled at a cost of L.E.700.

div.head: THE HOTEL DES BAINS,
div.p: Helouan, was opened yesterday. Many improvements have been made for the coming season, and pension may now be had from P.T.40 upwards.

div.head: STREET ASPHALTING.
div.p: The Ministry of Public Works proposes to asphalte 16,000 sq. metres of road space in Cairo, notably in the Mousky, Mohamed Aly, Abdeen, Bab el-Hadid, and Abdul Aziz quarters.

div.head: AMERICAN MISSION.-
div.p: In the English service of the American Mission at Tantah next Sabbath, the sermon will be appropriate to the semi-centennial celebration of the beginning of the work of the Mission in Egypt.

div.head: CANON DAVIS MEMORIAL.-
div.p: The medallion portrait is now placed in St. Mark's Church. The dedication service will be held later in the winter, on the occasion of the next visit of Bishop Blyth to this city.

div.head: THE HIRED TRANSPORT
div.p: Dilwara (Capt. A. W. Mann) came out of the Canal at 9 o'clock yesterday morning, and sailed shortly after for Colombo, Singapore, and Hongkong. She is due to return to Suez with troops on the 17th January next.

div.head: LECTURE BY M. SILVAIN.
div.p: Owing to the number of performances which M. Silvain is giving at Alexandria and Cairo having been suddenly modified, the lecture which the great actor is to deliver for the benefit of the Free Popular University has been unavoidably postponed to Friday, 25th inst.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL-
div.p: On the 15th inst., 15 vessels passed through the Suez Canal. Of these, 7 were British, 3 German, 1 Norwegian, 1 Italian, 1 Duteh, and 1 Danish. The transit and passenger dues for the day amounted to 412,867.56 frs. The total transit and passenger dues collected from the 1st to that date on 181 vessels amounted to 4,817,900.60 frs.

div.head: THE ST. LOUIS EXHIBITION.-
div.p: The numerous pupils and friends of the Berlitz schools in Egypt will be pleased to learn that these schools have just been awarded the "Grand Prix" at the International Exhibition at St. Louis. This flattering testimony-for it is the highest reward granted by the jury to a scholastic institution-proves in what esteem the Berlitz method is held by competent judges.

div.head: MR. GOULD'S COACHMAN ATTACKED-
div.p: Yesterday afternoon, while H.B.M.'s Consul-General at Alexandria was driving near the Custom- house police-station, the coachman told a Greek to get out of the way. The mán, apparently annoyed at this order, seized Mr. Gould's driver by the coat, struck him, and tried to drag him from the box. The police took the man, who appeared to be drunk, into custody.

div.head: BRITISH RECREATION CLUB-
div.p: A concert was given at this club yesterday evening. A number of songs were given by the members of the club. Mrs. Holmes and Miss Curtis were, as usual, excellent. Mr. Patterson gave a magnificent rendering of "The Storm Fiend," which fairly brought down the house. Mr. Lloyd Jones's and Master Willie Hayes's efforts are also worthy of mention. There was a very large attendance.

div.head: A JEWISH BENEVOLENT SOCIETY
div.p: was founded at Cairo on the 12th inst. for the Ashkenazi section of the community. It is styled "Ezras Nedouchim." The Rabbi of the Ashkenazi, M. A. M. Cohen, has been elected honorary president of the society. The other officials are as follows: M. Seidenberg, president; M. Kurzvail, treasurer; M. J. Feldstein, secretary; M. Goldenberg, vice-secretary; and Messrs. Z. Sehtatland, J. Newman, L Goldenberg, M. Goldenstein, and E. Grunstein, members of the committee.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive attended midday prayers to-day at the Mosque of Saida Zenab.

The committee for the organisation of the Khedivial Accession Fêtes held a meeting on Monday at the residence of Moudi Bey Ahmed, treasurer of the committee. Among those present were Mahmoud Pasha Chouery, Bassili Pasha Tadros, Joseph Bey Cattani, Mohamed Bey Hassan, M. Constantin Meimarachi, Moudid Bey Ahmed, and Aly Eff. Mandour. Those gentle men elected Abdul Hamid Pasha Sadek as chairman in succession to Abdul Kader Pasha Hilmy, who has resigned owing to his approaching departure for Vienna for an ophthalmic operation. The committee will meet again on the 10th prox. in order to draw up a programme of the fêtes on Accession Day.

div.head:
BALTIC FLEET.
WARNINGS TO BRITISH STEAMERS.
EXTRAORDINARY PRECAUTIONS.
div.p: At the request of the Governor of Suez, H.M.'s Pro-Consul at Suez has informed all the shipping agencies that they are to warn the commanders of British ships passing through the Suez Canal to take every measure to prevent any demonstration on board their Ships, and especially to prevent anything being thrown overboard while the Russian fleet is passing them. All mooring boats are also to be hoisted on board at the time.

The Canal Company, I hear, intends to stop all the traffic in the Canal, and thus leave a free passage to the Baltic squadron. Several ships which may be near the Bitter Lakes will have to anchor there.
The departure of the Russian fleet from Dakar without, apparently, taking in coal, requires some explanation.

The port of Dakar is in the French colony of Senegal. It is the most favourable point for coaling ships going round the Cape as it is more directly en route than the usual coaling stations in Madeira and the Azores. The idea of coaling there was a good one and no doubt the Russians reckoned upon the French per mitting them to coal within the limits of the harbour without taking coal from land. The French had, however, granted a concession to a French company which was in the hands of an English direction giving them the monopoly of coaling ships in the harbour. The neutrality of the French, who have behaved in strict orthodoxy through the war, would in any case probably have been maintained, even if no other interests were involved.

div.head: AT HOME" ON THE PSARA."
div.p: One of the most enjoyable social functions of the Alexandria season, which perhaps marked the climax of the festivities in connection with the Greek Fleet's visit, took place yester day afternoon, when Commodore Coundouriotis and the officers of the squadron were "at home" on board the flagship Psara. Something like 800 invitations had been sent out for the occasion, and fully that number enjoyed the hospitality of the popular naval men yesterday. The decks of the vessel had been entirely covered in for the occasion and beauti fally decorated inside with flags and bunting, one of the features of the scheme of decoration being an old flag which had belonged to a former vessel, named the Peara, that took part in the War of Independence. The whole ship, too, was brilliantly illuminated with a multitude of electric lights, and the appearance of the ship after night had fallen was very pleasing. The lower deck had been trans- formed into a very attractive ballroom, while above and below two large supper-rooms had been improvised, the whole being arranged in the most tasteful and artistic manner.

The proceedings commenced at 3.30 p.m., when the long stream of guests began to arrive, the steam launches of the warships being placed at their disposal to convey them from the quay. Commodore Coundouriotis received his guests at the top of the ship's gangway, and shortly afterwards tea was partaken of by the early arrivals.

Visitors, however, continued to arrive until an advanced hour, and about 5 o'clock the ex- cellent band of the ship struck up the first dance tune. Dancing was thenceforward in- dulged in with the very greatest animation up to midnight, the entrain never flagging for a moment. Some members of the fair sex, of whom there was a strong contingent, had taken the precaution to attire themselves in evening wear, and the ball-room at the height of the dancing, the uniforms of the officers mingling with the bright dresses of the ladies, with a background of vari-coloured flags, pre- sented a very fine coup d'ail.

At 7 p.m., the supper-rooms were thrown open, and the many good things spread out on the long tables were done ample justice to. The menu reflected great, credit on its composer, and was appreciated by all. The health of the Hellenic Fleet, proposed by Mr. E. Benachi, president of the Greek community, was drunk in champagne, and the greatest of good spirits prevailed throughout the evening.
It would be futile to attempt to give a list of even the most prominent people who were on board.

div.head: KASR-EL-NIL BRIDGE
div.p: "Unicorn" (Cairo) writes:-Choosing by preference, like your correspondent, to employ the "marrow-bone stage," I am able to cor roborate and sympathise with his animad- versions regarding the narrowness of the foot- path on the bridge. At the same time, it seems to me that much should be forgiven the engineer who designed that bridge, for on examining a "plaque" upon it I find that it was manufactured in France in the year 1870-1871. The man who planned that construction so many years ago and erected a lion at each of its corners, was gifted in a quite uncommon, degree with what has recently been characterised as "the power of intelligent anticipation," and it fully accords with the fitness of things that, at a moment like the present, when the Anglo-French Agreement has just received its final ratification, the lions and their pedestals should have been furbished with fresh paint and plaster and made to p-look spick and span. It has, however, always remained an Egyptian mystery to me why the sin second rather than the first of the two bridges ro-spanning the Nile should have been baptised "Pont des Anglais."

div.head:
FATAL EXPLOSION IN CAIRO.
STEAM LAUNCH BLOWN UP.
THREE MEN KILLED.
div.p: Yesterday afternoon the boiler of a steam launch moored about 150 yards short of the Kasr-el-Nil Bridge exploded violently. The launch was torn to pieces, fragments of the debris falling in the parade ground of Kasr-el- Nil barracks.
The launch disappeared instantly in a cloud of steam and smoke and with her a Greek engineer and two Arabs who were on board. The cause of the accident is unknown.

The launch belongs to the Anglo-American Company and had been used as a ferry be- tween Assouan and Elephantine Island. She was recently sent down to Boulao on account of some engine defects. After the boilers had been repaired, she went through two trial trips with great success and left Boulac yesterday at 1 p.m. for Assouan. She had just started when the catastrophe occurred.

div.head: ISLAND OF THASOS.
div.p: The administration of the Sultan's private properties has concluded a contract with Messrs. Gebrueder Speidel, of Pforzheim, Grand Duchy of Baden, for the exploitation of all the Galmei (calamine), silver, lead, and copper mines existing in the Island of Thasos.

div.head: CAIRO GARRISON.
div.p: Two or three companies of the 2nd Battalion Royal Berkshire Regiment are proceeding to Cairo in the first week of December in order to form part of the garrison at Cairo.

div.head: THE WADY RAYAN.
div.p: The Newport Herald, U.S.A., of the 19th ult contains the following curious paragraph:-- "Steps have been taken to secure the friendly intervention of the government of the United States to secure the completion of the Rayan sluiceways before next August. Either let the Anglo-Egyptian engineers show adequate energy; or, as in the case of the Atbars bridge, the Americans will do it for them at a cost in money and expenditure of time, which will be a mere fmotion of the latest English estima- tion."
We wonder if Mr. Cope-Whitehouse is responsible for this.

div.head: GUM ARABIC.
div.p: The prices of gum remained very firm all through October. About

have been sold and holders have been satisfied with the opportunity of liquidating a good part of their stock at prices which, if not sa tisfactory, were at least not ridiculously low. The total loss suffered by the gum traders of the Sudan, owing to their having been obliged to lower their prices during the last campaign, is estimated at from £12,000 to £15,000.

div.head: A BOON FOR CAIRO.
div.p: An interesting experiment is shortly to be started in Cairo for the benefit of both visitors and residents. This innovation is due to an Anglo-Indian lady, whose hobby it is to found the most luxurious and perfectly appointed home for sick people which money and medical skill can devise.

The Hutchinson Nursing Home, named thus after the foundress, Mrs. Arthur Hutchinson, late of Bath, is situated in the quietest and most central part of Cairo. It is in Sharis el- Falaki, close to Bab-el-Louk station. It is fitted with every modern appliance that science and skill can devise, to provide comfort, hygiene, and perfect sanitation, combined with professional medical and surgical attention and attendance. The establishment is heated and lighted entirely by electricity, and the arrange- ment of the switches for moveable lamps, fans, stoves, and bells, has been very carefully thought out, so as to give the patient the greatest comfort with the least possible trouble. The sanitary work has been carried out by a well-known firm of sanitary engineers, whose certificate can be inspected on the premises. The operating theatre, which has been A thoroughly disinfected and enamelled through- out, is fitted with the latest antiseptic operative farniture and appliances, and adjoins the rooms set apart for surgical cases. Special nurses are reserved to look after this depart ment. Baths are provided on each floor. Special attention is paid to the culinary depárt ment, which is under the charge of an Indian cook. The servants are mostly Goanese boys, all of whom were known by the lady super- intendent in India. The resident medical officer lives in a separate house in the grounds, and can be in attendance at any time. An efficient staff of nurses, trained in every department, has been especially engaged from London, under the supervision of a competent matron. Patients sent to the Home by their own medical men will be attended by them, the resident medical officer only acting as house surgeon. Other patients will be under the care of the resident medical officer, but have the option of choosing any surgeon or physician they prefer in the neighbourhood. Medical men in all parts of the world will find this excellent Home to which to send their patients, for no trouble or expense has been spared to make it a most up-to-date Sanatorium.

div.head:
COST OF LIVING IN CAIRO.
PETITION TO FINANCE MINISTER
div.p: A petition lately forwarded to the Minister of Finance by a number of the employés of the Ministry contains tables showing the rise in the prices of commodities since the year 1885. We quote the tables below but must express our opinion that the increase in certain items has been exaggerated and that others which are set down in the tables are very cryptic. For instance, what is the meaning of "other expenses for civilisation?" Does this refer to the clerk's patronage of music and the drama ? If so, he surely spends less than LE, 10 on the arts. Perhaps some of our readers can check the table that follows:

Then we have two lists, one of which shows the monthly expenses of an employé getting LE 6 per mensem, while the other shows the expenses of an improvident person who, with the same salary, boasts a wife and 2 children.

row.cell: 7.500 involving 1.500 to the bad every month.

div.p: Doctors and school expenses are not quoted, and we note that the married man spends nothing on hair-dressing !

div.head: PARCEL POST.
div.p: A correspondent writes: Would it not be possible for the Post Office Administration of Cairo to expedite the delivery of parcels ar riving by parcel post! Twenty minutes is a long time to have to wait, and it is not above the average delay, which is peculiarly irksome to those who have no servants to send there. The Government does not appear to grasp that the work of the Egyptian Post Office is in- creasing by leaps and bounds and that it is absolutely necessary to largely increase, the staff of this Administration. It is sipoerely to be hoped that the Finance Ministry will be more liberal in its dealings with the Postal Administration in the forthcoming budget.

div.head: THE BANK OF ROME IN EGYPT.
div.p: A Cairo correspondent, writing to a London contemporary on the subject of the foundation of a branch of the Bank of Rome in Egypt, re- marks: This, I believe, will be the first in- stance of an Italian bank extending its opera tions ultra mare since the period when the great banking street of London was christened, with the name of the Lombards."

div.head: SHEPHEARD'S HOTEL
div.p: By kind permission of Major C. J: L. David son, D.8.0., commanding, and officers 2nd Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, the Band will play the following programme on the terrrace of Shepheard's Hotel on Saturday afternoon from 4 to 6:
March-Hands across the Bes Bouss Pas de deux-Beanly of the Dance-Busby.. Oyertare-Masaniello-Auber.
Serenade Espagnole-La Manola Eilenberg. Selection-Reminiscences of the Plantation Cham.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellerman S.S. City of Venice sails to-day for Liverpool direct, with passengers and general cargo.
The Ellerman S.S. City of Khior arrived at Liverpool from Alexandris yesterday morning.
The Westcott S.S. Perim sailed to-day for Limassol in ballast
The Moss liner Tabor sailed bence yesterday afternoon for Liverpool via Malta, with passen gers, mails and general cargo, including 4,082 bales cotton.

div.head: Anglo-American Nile Steamer & Hotel Company
div.p: River Transport of Goods Between Alexandria & Cairo

div.head:
CAIRO POISONING CASE.
SENTENCE ON ACCUSED.
div.p: As we go to press we learn by telepho from our Cairo Correspondent that the accused in the famous Nacamuli poisoning case ha been sentenced by the Italian Consular Court to six months and 20 days imprisonment of the charge of manslaughter brought against him, with the option of paying a fine of 2,000 frs, and costs.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H. B. Ghazi Mukhtar Pasha, Imperial Otto- man High Commissioner, gaye an "ar Moslem notables yesterday evening, and to hight will give an "Iftar" to pashas
Mrs. Butcher regrets tosay that, owing to the llness of Dean Butcher and Professor Sayos at Church House, she will not be able to receive.. her friends on Saturday next, the 19th..
M. Coquelin and his company left Alex- andria yesterday afternoon by the Florio Rubattino S.S. Cairo en route for Rome.
Drs. Takvorian Arshag, Ward Campbell, and Abdel-Kerim Mohamed have been authorised to exercise their profession in Egypt

div.head: PASSENGER LISTS.
div.p: Le paquebot Nilo, de la Cie Florio-Rubat- tino parti le 15 pour Venise, avait à bord MM. Sarmel Balls, Italo Momoni, F. Peretti, Maria Peretti, W, N. Ensham, Max Vernoni, et 14 passagers de 3me classe.
Le paquebot Cairo, de la Cie Florio-Rubat tino parti hier pour, Gênes, avait à bord:

MM. Georghe, P. de Santis, Louis. Falquet, FE. Hipple, M. et Mme Brassy-Block, P. Chiesa, comp. Coquelin, M. et Mme Roberts M. Castelli, Mile F. Maksud, A. Heberlain, G. Siletti, G. Bucan, et 27 passagers de Supe classe
Per Moss S.S. Tabor, left yesterday for Malta and Liverpool:-Mr. P. Micallef.

div.head: CHRONIQUE THEATRALE
div.p: Grisslidis, type légendaire des vertus conju gales, a été mis sur la scène par MM-Armand Silvestre et Eug. Morand. Dans l'adaptation. qu'ils en ont faite on peut leur reprocher d'avoir trop peu songé que le public d'aujour d'hui n'est plus celui d'autrefois. Il eut été si simple pourtant avec un sujet qui après tout ne manque pas de charme ni de poésie de créer une pièce plus en rapport avec notre époque, plus vivante. Peu conforme au goût moderne" en France même, elle l'est encore moins dans un milieu égyptien et cosmopolite.

L'interprétation a été bonne. Le rôle princi pal, Grisélidis, a été dignement tepu par Mme Louise Silvain qui a su rendre à merveille toutes les délicates nuances de son personnage M. Werney s'est remué comme un beau diabla qu'il était, M. Renaud a été expellent dans Alain et Miles Belyal et Barat dans Fiamina et Bertrade. Dans le rôle un peu effacé da Marquis de Salluces, M. Silvain s'est montré Admirable.
Comme intermède il a dit trois monologues très applaudis, entre autres La Conscience, de Victor Hugo.

Nous devons une mention spéciale à Mme Silvain et à Mile Barat pour leur interpreta tion exquise du Passant, de François Copple de délicieux petit chef-d'œuvre à deux person- nages a été rendu d'une façon vraiment.excep tionnelle.
Ce soir on donne Horace, tragédie en 5 actes de Pierre Corneille; et la Femme de Tabarin, tragi parade cu 1 acte de Catulle Mendès.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: En dépit de la mauvaise humeur qui régne sur les marchés européens, notre place se main- tient ferme et en hausse.
La Banque Nationale atteint 241/4 acheteurs ep hausse d'une 1/2 livre, l'Agricole 10 15/16, la Béhéra 57 en hausse de 2 livres et demie, la Delta 15 3/8, les Cotton Mills 7/6
Par contre la Salt & Soda fléchit à 38/6 vendeurs par suite des réalisations, la Nungo- vich à 9 5/16, l'Anglo American Nile à 55/16 et les Eaux du Caire à 1070.
En sympathie avec Paris la Banque d'Athènes fléchit ici à 126 pour reprendre en clôture 130 acheteurs.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Ten minutes from Alexandria. First-Class in every respect. Very moderate charges. Bulkeley is the fashionable English quarter. Visitors from Cairo alight at Sidi Gaber Station.

div.head: LE PORT D'ALEXANDRIE
div.p: Le port d'Alexandrie prend un dévelop pement tel que le moment est venu de jeter un coup d'oeil rétrospectif et étudier sa marche progressive afin d'éveiller l'at- tention du commerce et de la marine mar- chande.

Le tonnage des navires entrés dans notre port n'a pas eu l'ascension vertigineuse de Hambourg, d'Anvers, de Gênes, ni mêm celle moins rapide de Marseille; nous n'a- vons pas en Egypte l'industrie toujours en progrès qui fait agrandir les ports, multi- tiplier les voies de communication, mais notre agriculture a augmenté dans de telles proportions, la prospérité du pays est telle que le port d'Alexandrie ne suffit déjà plus au mouvement des affaires. Il a heureuse- ment une surface d'eau abritée, immense, comme un très petit nombre de ports en possò lent, mais il n'a pas assez de murs d quais. Nous apprenons que le Gouverne ment s'est ému de cet état de choses et est décidé à allouer un crédit très important pour créer de nouveaux accostages.

De 1890 à 1908 le tonnage total des na- vires entrés dans le port d'Alexandrie est passé de 1 682 000 à 2.782.000 tonneaux Il atteindra 3.115.000 tonneaux en 1904, si on en juge d'après les résultats des neuf premiers mois.

De 1840 à 1880 le tonnage passe lente ment de 400 000 tonneaux à 1.200.000 tonneaux. De 1880 à 1904, la marche est. beaucoup plus rapide et nous avons ajour- d'hui un tonnage deux fois et demi plu- grand.

Notre port a atteint l'importance de ceux de Barcelone, Alger, Copenhague, Melbourne, Sydney, Naples, Le Havre, Southampton; il a dépassé ceux d+ Bor- deaux, Dankerque, Smyrne, Trieste, Ve- nise, Amsterdam, Oleses, Bombay, Cal- cutta, Montréal, Rio de Janeiro, Philadel phie, pour n'en citer que quelques-uns des plus connus

L'étude comparative des grands port de Liverpool, Hambourg, Anvers, des au- tres moins importants, Marseille et Gênes et enfin des ports plus petits, le Havre, Trieste, Alexandrie, Bordeaux, permettra de juger de l'importance relative de notre port. Son tonnage total est à peu près le 1/5 de celui de Londres, les 3/10 de Liverpool, d'Anvers, d'Hambourg, les 4/10 de Marseille; il est une fois et demi celui de Bordeaux, près de 2 fois celui de Dunkerque ou de Boulogne, trois fois celui de Cette et de Rouen. Nous allons voir maintenant l'importance de la marine marchande des. nationalités anglaise, française, italienne, austro-hongroise, russe, ottomane, alle- mande et la marche du tonnage total de leurs navires. L'Angleterre tient la tête avec 1,195,000 tonneaux, c'est-à-dire qua- tre fois comme pour la France et l'Italie qui n'en ont que 305,000 et 307,000. La marine allemande qui, en 1890, comptait à peine 18,000 tonneaux est passée à 125,000 dans le courant de ces treize années, elle tend à prendre rang parmi les nations qui font le plus de commerce avec l'Egypte et aura bientôt atteint l'Italie. L'Angleterre est toujours en tête, avec ses cotonnades, charbons et machines. La Turquie se détache et prend franchement le second rang, parce qu'elle importe des marchandises de grande valeur comme le tabac et les animaux de boucherie. Vien. nent ensuite la France avec ses farines, ses tissus, ses fers ouvrés, se vias et liqueurs, l'Autriche avec ses bois, ses vête- ments de confection et ses papiers, l'Italie Avec ses soieries, ses på es alimentaires, ses huiles, ses vins, etc., l'Allemagne avec ses fers, ses tissus et ea quincaillerie, la Russie avec son pétrole, ta farine et son bois.

Pendant cette période de 13 années, le tonnage total des navires anglais a augmenté de 60 0/0, celai de la France de 20 0/0, celui de l'Autriche de 35 0/0, celai de l'Italie a quadruplé, tandis que le com- merce de l'Angleterre a augmenté de 80 0/0, celui de la France de 120 0/0, celui de l'Autriche de 60 0/0, celui de l'Italie a quadruplé.

Nous voyons par là qu'il n'existe pas toujours de proportion entre la valeur des marchandises importées par une nation et le tonnage total de sa marine marchande. Cela tient probablement à ce que certaines nations, la Franca et l'Allemagne par exemple, transportent une partie de leurs marchandises sous pavillon étranger et aussi que les bateaux sont quelquefois très peu chargés.

Nous savons aussi que la plupart des bateaux arrivant pleins s'en vont aux trois qusrts vides, parce que l'Egypte n'expédie en poids ou volume qu'un quart à peine de ce qu'elle reçoit, et cependant la valeur des marchandises à l'exportation est sapérieure à celle des importations.

La raison est la suivante: le coton, la principale marchandise exportée, a une valear très grande sous un faible volume tandis que le charbon, le bois, le fer, les principaux articles importés ont pea de Valur sous un gros volume.

Da toutes ces considérations on tire les conclusions suivantes: la moyenne des touages des bateaux à voile, qui était de 124 tonneaux en 1890, est descendue à 100 en 1908, tandis que celle des bateaux à Vaprorsugmenté de 1343 tonnesur à 1700 tonneaux.
C'est la France qui a les bateaux de plus fort tonnage avec une moyenne de 2.600; viennent ensuite l'Autriche avec 2.200 ton., l'Italie avec 1.750, l'Angleterre avec 1 700.

Alexandrie fournit le 89 0/0 du com merce d'importation de toute l'Egypte et 97,50 0/0, de celui d'exportation. En 1902 un a importé 860,000 ton. de charbon de terre, 29,000 ton. de charbon de bois, 250,000 ton. environ de bois de construe- tion, 20,000 ton. de bois de chauffage, 82,000 ton. de farine, 40,000 ton. de riz, 6,660 ton. de tabac, 22,000 ton. d'étoffee, 90,000 ton. environ de fers et métaux, soit au total environ 2,300,000 tonnes.
On a exporté 293,000 tonnes de coton, 840,000 hectolitres de graines de coton, 50,000 tonnes d'oignoas, 480,000 hecto- aires de fèves soit au total 565,000 tonnes de marchandises.

Les quais du port reçoivent un tonnage considérable de marchandises. La longueur des murs accostables pour les bateaux à vapeur est de 8.500 mètres pouvant rece- voir 80 bateaux, celle des quais utilisabl- s seulement par les voiliers est de 2,300 Lètres.

Nous trouvons qu'en 1904 chaque mètre de quai accostable sura reça 1.650 ton- neaux de jauge, tandis que Marseille, qui a 18.000 mètres de quais accostables pour graads bateaux, n'en reçoit que 800 à 900, mais, en revanche, nous avons une surface d'eau de 750 Hectares dont 200 hectares parfaitement abrités tandis que Marseille, n'a que 197 hectares de surface d'eau. Ceci explique que malgré l'insuffisance de murs de quai, le port actuel suffit au dé- barquement des navires qui peuvent opérer leur déch srgement par chalands et mahon- nes lorsque ceux-ci ne trouvent pas de place à quai.
Cette immense surface, abritée par le brise-lames, permet à pea de frais l'établis sement de nouveaux murs d'accostage tandis que dans les autres ports le moindre agrandissement devient très onéreux.
Extrait du Bulletin de la Chambre de Commerce Française.)

div.head:
ZUBAIR PASHA.
HIS AUTOBIOGRAPHY.
BY PROFESSOR MARGOLIOUTH.
div.p: The name of Zubair Pasha is only remembered in connection with Gordon's last and fatal mission to the Sudan. Watching the progress of Mahdism as it overran the Sudan, the English Governor, from the day of his arrival at Khartoum, "urged in the strongest terms that he could employ that power should be placed in the hands of a single man, and that man Zobair Pasha." (1) This recommenda tion he continued to urge in the most per- sistent way; and the Journals of his last months at Khartoum contain many an expres- sion of regret at the rejection of his advice, and of his belief in the marvellous influence which Zubair could have exercised over the minds of the Sudanese. That Gordon should have longed for the co-operation of Zubair was indeed a noteworthy case of the whirligig of time bringing its revenges. That co-operation had been offered him in 1879 at the time of "the Slave-dealers' Rebellion" by Nubar Pasha, and he had rejected it with scorn; (2) declaring that Zubair alone was responsible for the slave trade of the last ten years. (3) The re- fusal of the British Government in 1884 to let Zubair be sent to assist Gordon was due to the representations of an Anti-Slavery Society; (4) but indeed in Hill's edition of Gordon's Letters Zubair had been described in a way which would prevent any self-respect- ing Government from making such a man a K.C.M.G., or indeed employing him in any capacity whatever. The passage is fervidly rhetorical, as follows: (5)

"On one great criminal had not yet fallen the punishment due to his boundless wicked- ness. Sebehr Pasha had been a king among the slave-traders of the world. His strong holds had been pushed far into the heart of Africa; and over hundreds of miles of fertile lands, whose fruits had once nourished a teeming and a happy population, he had spread desolation and sorrow. He had kept up an almost princely court; but the flood of his prosperity had been swollen to its monstrous height by the tears of thousands and tens of thousands. The ebb had at length come, and for a time that vast stream of human misery had ceased to flow. To add yet a deeper stain to his guilt, he had been a traitor to the government under which he held high office. He was a Pasha of Egypt, and against Egypt he had raised this fierce revolt. By his orders her troops had been treacherously surprised and massacred." Who then was this Zubair, who, in the first set of Gordon's Journals figures as the villain of the piece, and in the last as a benevolent deus ex machina, on whose approach the star of the Mahdi would at once begin to wane 1 Gordon's biographers ordinarily describe him as a scoundrel (6) and a notorious slave-trader. A fairly detailed account of him and his career is given by the traveller, W. Junker, whose work has been translated into English by Mr. A. H. Keane; (7) another (not yet translated), which agrees with the former in most matters, by the contemporary traveller, Nachtigal; (8) and an Arabic biography of Zubair was published by Gordon himself. (9) In the present year, however, Zubair has published his autobiography, which he commu- nicated orally to Na'oum Bey Shoucair, Chef de Bureau in the Agent-General's office, Cairo, who has incorporated it in his monumental work on the history, geography, and physical characteristics of the Sudan; (10) a work acces sible at present to Arabic scholars only. Owing to the remarkable manner in which Zubair figures in the Journals of the "Christian Hero," there may be many in England who would like to know more about him. We shall there- fore abridge his autobiography, and then estimate the amount of justification which it gives for the above treatment of him.

note.p: (1) Sir H. W Gordon, in Gordon's Journals," edited by Hake. 1858, p. lvii.
(2) Cel. Gordon in Central Afries," by Birkbeck Bil 181, p. 886.
(4) H. D. Traill, "England, Egypt and the Sudan," 1900 p. 74.
(5) "Col. Gordon in Central Africa," p. S.S. The werde sre Hill'
(6) A. E. Hake, Gorlon in Chins and the Sudan," 18 6, p. 181; ef D. O Boulger, "Life ef Gordon" 1996 i 149.
(9) PirH W Gordor, Charles George Gordon," 1+80, p. 881,
(10) The History and Geography of the Sudan," Cairo, 1904.

div.p: Zubair, (1) son of Rahmat, was born on an island in the White Nile called Wawissa, in the year 1881. He regards himself as a descendant of the Abbasid family, which gave Caliphs to Baghdad for more than five centa ries. When the Mongols put an end to the series his ancestors fled to Egypt. But, disliking the rule of the Fatimides (which, by the way, had ceased for a century), they went South, and emerge in the nineteenth century as members of the tribe Jami'ab, located in Darfur. At the age of seven he was sent to school at Khartoum, which even before the erection of Gordon College was regarded as a seat of learning.

His family were traders, and his first expedi tion of importance was brought about by his anxiety to dissuade a cousin from undertaking a hazardous journey into Bahr el-Ghazal. The cousin refused to be dissuaded; and Zubair, who was then twenty-five years of age, swore, under penalty of divorcing his wife, that either the cousin must yield, or he himself would share the perils of the journey. As his cousin. persisted, Zubair was compelled by his oath to make the journey also. They took with them a supply of beads and other ornaments, to be exchanged for ivory, rhinoceros horn, ostrich feathers, and other products of the Bahr el- Ghazal province. Both of them were in the employ of that Ali Abu Amouri whose name occurs occasionally in Schweinfurth's "Travels" (2) and Sir S. Baker's "Ismailia." (3)

An occasion soon arose enabling Zubair to display some of his talents. An attack was made on the traders by the natives of the Jur country, where were pitched the zareebahs of the party. Zubair organised the defence, and, probably owing to the possession of superior weapons, defeated the assailants with great slaughter. Thereafter the traders began to look to Zubair as their natural protector; Ali Abu Amouri gave him a tenth of his ivory, and ap- pointed him his agent when he left for Khar- toum. By 1858 Zubair was himself able to re- turn to Khartoum with profits valued at £1,000. With this sum he purchased a dahabieh, loaded it with goods, and hired a company whom he armed with rifles. His intention was to explore unknown lands.

This intention he presently carried out. Leaving his dahabieh at the furthest navigable point on the Bahr el-Ghazal (4) he proceeded across country to the region called Kolou, (5) where he was favourably received by the ruler, and collected great stores of ivory. Thence in 1859 he advanced westward to the Nyamn-yam country, where reigned a king with four hundred wives, and where camels, horses, and asses were unknown. Zubair would have presented the king with an ass, but the king thought it must be a man magically transformed and would have none of it. But other presents won his favour, and he gave Zubair the eldest of his many daughters. Alliance with the king enabled him to do business with safety and success.

His return was marked by a strange adven- ture. He and his former employer endeavoured to save themselves a long land journey by navigating the Pongo, a tributary of the Bahr el-Ghazal. They built themselves a couple of boats, and embarked, taking two months' pro- visions; but presently the tributary widened out into a vast lake unknown, it would appear, to the maps-where they lost their bearings, and were compelled to wander se- venty-five days. Then they perceived some smoke, which it was found proceeded from a large and populous island in the lake, where in the afternoon quantities of ox-dung were burnt in order to provide ash-beds for the inhabitants to lie on at night. Thither they proceeded, having already lost several of their number from privation or despair. On their arrival at the island, where they were hospit rably received, many more perished, through "partaking too greedily of the first meal offered them.

The hospitality was, however, only a cloak for treachery; the king of the island arranged that a night attack should be made on the guests, themselves slaughtered and their goods seized. But Zubair, who was keeping guard, shot a lion, which, like its ancestor of Nemes, had been devastating the island, and this drove all idea of treachery from the king's heart, who proceeded to bestow a daughter on the hero. But on leaving the island fresh "disasters overtook the party, and only Zubair, his former employer, and six men got back me safely to Khartoum.

note.p: (1) The form ebehr was got by Gordon from the Eng'ish translation of Schweinfurth's Travels," where the Germanised form was retsined unaltered.
(5) Called Golo in A. H. Keane's Africs," 1895-

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: The Press here records with gratification the presence of the Khedive at the King's Birth- day review at Cairo the 9th inst.
Captain E.N. Tandy, who was lately serving with No. 4 Mountain Battery in Egypt, has been appointed adjutant of the Ordnance College.
Second-Lieutenant A. St. J. Loftus, Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, will embark about the 17th inst. for Egypt to join the 2nd Battalion at Cairo.

The 16th (Queen's) Lancers arrived home yesterday from the Cape and proceeded to Colchester. The regiment went from India to the front in January, 1900, and distinguished itself in French's operations.
It is officially notified that the new period of enlistment-nine years with the Colours and three in the Reserve-does not interfere with the extensions of soldiers serving under the old terms.

Attention is drawn in Army Orders to the fact that applications continue to reach the War Office for the writing-off or adjustment of items of account and balances due to the South African war. The Army Council con- siders that the time has long passed when such transactions should be outstanding, and it desires that immediate attention should be given to the matter by all concerned. Except in very special cases the Army Council will be compelled to refuse relief from Army funds unless applications forwarded through the recognised official channels are received in the office by November 30, 1904, in the case of home stations, and January 31, 1905, in the case of stations abroad.

I understand that, so far from any reduction of the Mediterranean Fleet being contemplated, it will be kept at the highest possible state of efficiency. Some smaller ships will be with drawn, but this will in no way impair the effi- ciency of the Fleet but rather increase it. As soon as ready for sea the magnificent first-class battleship King Edward VII. will join Sir Compton E. Domvile's flag.

The world-renowned firm of Vickers, Sons and Maxim, Ltd., Barrow-in-Furness, has just made a record in battleship speed. The new first-class battleship H.M.S. Dominion, built, engined, and armed by the firm, lately went through her speed trials under war conditions -engine-room closed, bulkheads closed, and the staff representing the crew at quarters. Under these conditions the Dominion reeled off 19 knots, which is better than anything the Royal dockyards have yet done.

div.head: THE ARABIAN TROUBLES.
div.p: From further details of the troubles in the Nejd country it appears that Ibn Rashid is. confined at Hail, north-west of E'Riad, where he is completely in the power of the followers of Ibn Saud.

The Turkish authorities will therefore prob- ably abandon the idea of sending him reinforce- ments, as they fear that the disturbance will spread, and they will confine themselves to endeavouring to bring about peace between the two chiefs by means of negotiations.

div.head: PROGRESS OF GREECE.
div.p: A report for the year 1904 of the finances, economic progress, and agriculture of Greece has been issued by the Foreign Office. The Budget for 1904 shows a total of 121,486,246dr., or an apparent increase of 991,884dr. The real increase is, howewer, 2,991,884dr., the receipts for 1903 having been swollen by the fictitious item of 2,000,000dr. on account of the reduction of forced currency. The Budget as a whole shows the receipts to have been 121,186,246dr., and the expenditure 120,200,247dr., leaving an estimated surplus of 985,999dr. In spite of unfavourable political conditions, it is stated that the country has made substantial economic progress in the last decade. Currants, which with corn form the staple commodity of the country, have reached the maximum point of production, attaining a figure far in excess of the world's natural demand. Corn, on the other hand, offers large possibilities. At the present time Greece imports cereals to the value of nearly £1,500,000, which is roughly the value of the currants it exports. There is good reason to suppose that with a better supply of labour and better agricultural methods Greece could provide itself with all the grain required for home consumption, and thus wipe out the heavy debtor item in the country's international balance-sheet.

div.head: EGYPT AT THE LORD MAYOR'S SHOW.
div.p: Describing the pageant at the Lord Mayor's Show last week, the Daily Telegraph says:- The organisers showed themselves greatly daring in the spectacular element in question, but had the good sense to avoid emulation of their pre- decessors who, some twenty-five years ago, sought to secure a unique effect with a peram- bulating Cleopatra's Needle, attended, accord- ing to a chronicler of the day, by "a pair of double-humped dromedaries ridden by burnt- cork Egyptians, and elephants controlled by stage Nubians." Yesterday we had "Ancient Egypt," but unaccompanied, happily, by any such incongruous adjuncts. The emblematic car so styled was the first of four, and, like the rest, was drawn by six fine draught horses. Its design showed sphinxes guarding a stairway. leading to a pillar, upon which, beneath a handsome canopy, was a statue of the Nile's deity. The sides of the vehicle and the pillar bore paintings taken from the papyrus of Ani- the historical accuracy of which, it may be hoped, duly impressed the assembled onlookers -while a representative of Pharaoh, together with priests and attendants in white raiment, stood on the car."

div.head: JEWS IN THE ARMY.
div.p: The Jewish Chronicle states that the Duke of Connaught, in a letter sent through his private secretary to the Rev. Francis L. Cohen, the Chaplain to the Jews in his Majesty's Forces, who has accepted the post of Minister to the Sydney Hebrew Congregation, New South Wales, expresses regret that it will be impossible for him to attend the annual Jewish military service on December 4, as his recent acci- dent has necessitated his keeping as quiet as possible for some weeks to come. The letter adds: "His Royal Highness is much interested to hear of the work which you have carried out in making the Army more popular amongst the Jewish community, and considers that the growth of the numbers of Jews who are now soldiers reflects great credit on your energy and zeal. For this reason, his Royal Highness notices with regret your pending departure from England, and hopes that your successor in this country may be moved to continue the excellent work which has been inaugurated and carried out by yourself."

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
